content: The Act is titled the "Hydrographic Services Improvement Act Amendments of 2008" and includes definitions for various terms. Section 303 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892) is amended to define 'hydrographic data' as information acquired through various surveying methods and used in providing hydrographic services. Hydrographic services involve managing, interpreting, certifying, and disseminating various types of information, including bathymetric, hydrographic, shoreline, geodetic, and geomagnetic data. This includes producing nautical charts, databases, and other products derived from hydrographic data, as well as developing nautical information systems. It also mentions related activities and defines the Coast and Geodetic Survey Act. SEC. 3. FUNCTIONS OF THE ADMINISTRATOR. Section 303 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892a) is amended to promote safe, efficient, and environmentally sound marine transportation by providing hydrographic services and fulfilling the duties of the Administration under the Coast and Geodetic Survey Act. The Administrator may procure, lease, evaluate, test, develop, and operate vessels, equipment, and technologies necessary for safe navigation and hydrographic data acquisition. They shall also design, install, maintain, and operate real-time hydrographic monitoring systems to enhance navigation safety and efficiency. The Administrator may acquire hydrographic data and provide services to support navigation safety, conservation of coastal resources, and emergency response efforts. The Administrator may create joint centers with other entities to support commerce in emergencies, disasters, and homeland security needs, and award contracts for hydrographic data acquisition. The Administrator may create joint centers with other entities to support commerce in emergencies, disasters, and homeland security needs, and award contracts for hydrographic data acquisition in accordance with relevant laws. SEC. 4. HYDROGRAPHIC SERVICES REVIEW PANEL. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 is amended to specify the composition of the panel, consisting of 15 voting members appointed by the Administrator, with nonvoting members including the Co-directors of the Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center and up to 2 NOAA employees. Voting members must be experts in hydrographic data and related fields. The Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 specifies that the panel must consist of 15 voting members appointed by the Administrator, who are experts in hydrographic data and related fields. These members should have experience in disciplines such as marine transportation, port administration, vessel pilotage, coastal and fishery management, and other relevant areas. SEC. 5. Authorization of appropriations under the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 is amended to read as follows. To carry out nautical mapping and charting functions, appropriations are authorized as follows: $55,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, $56,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $57,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $58,000,000 for fiscal year 2012. Additionally, funds for hydrographic surveys and vessel contracts are allocated as follows: $32,130,000 for fiscal year 2009, $32,760,000 for fiscal year 2010, and $33,390,000 for fiscal year 2011. Appropriations for hydrographic survey vessels and geodetic functions are allocated as follows: $25,900,000 for fiscal year 2009, $26,400,000 for fiscal year 2010, $26,900,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $27,400,000 for fiscal year 2012. Appropriations for geodetic functions and tide/current measurements are as follows: $32,640,000 for FY 2009, $33,280,000 for FY 2010, $33,920,000 for FY 2011, $34,560,000 for FY 2012, $27,000,000 for FY 2009, $27,500,000 for FY 2010, $28,000,000 for FY 2011, $28,500,000 for FY 2012. Additionally, $75,000,000 is allocated for acquiring a replacement hydrographic survey vessel. SEC. 6. Authorized NOAA Corps strength is amended to specify the number of authorized commissioned officers. Effective October 1, 2009, the total number of authorized commissioned officers in the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's commissioned corps will increase from 321 to 379, subject to conditions including submission of ship and aircraft plans, availability of funding, and justification of organizational needs.
